head.title: Cardiology Professor At Stanford Facing Harassment Charges

hedline.hl1: Cardiology Professor At Stanford Facing Harassment Charges

block.p: Stanford University has filed sexual harassment charges against a cardiologist at the university's medical school, based on complaints made by two female medical students.
The university president, Donald Kennedy, said Wednesday he had filed administrative harassment charges and professional misconduct charges against Dr. Mark Perlroth.
Stanford University has filed sexual harassment charges against a cardiologist at the university's medical school, based on complaints made by two female medical students.
The university president, Donald Kennedy, said Wednesday he had filed administrative harassment charges and professional misconduct charges against Dr. Mark Perlroth.

In a statement, the 53-year-old cardiologist said he "vigorously denied" the allegations and accused the administration of using him as a scapegoat for the embarrassment of unrelated charges of sexism made by a female surgeon who resigned last month.

The complaints against Dr. Perlroth were made by two students in December and February. One said Dr. Perlroth had made inappropriate sexual remarks; the other said he had denied her a teaching-assistant job because she refused to have sex with him.
The charges were filed with a seven-member faculty advisory board. Dr. Perlroth would have the right to appeal any sanctions.
In May, Dr. Frances Conley resigned from the School of Medicine, saying she had endured years of sexual harassment.
Stanford officials denied that there was any link. "The reason we publicized this is because it's so unusual," a Stanford lawyer, John Schwartz, said.
Complaints are usually handled internally, with the accused faculty member accepting a sanction to avoid public charges.
Mr. Kennedy said in a statement that he filed the charges after Dr. Perlroth refused to accept such sanctions.

In filing charges, Mr. Kennedy said he had recommended that if Dr. Perlroth is found guilty he should be disciplined through closer supervision and a possible one-year suspension without pay, but not dismissed.
